How does it feel to be free?
[At least more then before]
Well, I'm here

Hi, pretty good so far.
What about you?

Yeah, it can be stale around here, but you can pass some time looking through [ZeroSites](/Sites.ZeroNetwork.bit/), go to [millchan](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/) or talking to people in [ZeroTalk](/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/).
Also if you decide to go exploring: Keep in mind, that this is an decentralized network with no hosting costs, that can be made anonymous. You probably will, at some point, find cp(child porn). If you want to be (somewhat) protected against that you can use [Styromaniacs MOAB](/Styromaniac.blocklist.bit/)-blocklist, since it blocks all currently known cp zites(and a few other ones).
Personally, I wouldn't eat them after 2 weeks in the fridge.
I'm also here, now we can be alone, together.
So what is the context of that?

Depends on who you're hiding from. A state level actor(think government) will have significant trouble finding out who you are, if you are on tor always mode and using zeronet through the Tor Browser Bundle.
That said, zeronet over tor is significantly less anonymous than i2p and a bit less then just using tor(reason for that being that correlation and sybil attacks are more effective on the tor network the more individual connections you make, since zeronet uses torrents this makes it less anonymous than tor alone). ZeroNet over i2p would be optimal, but since there is currently only one dev really working on this it could take a while for i2p to arrive. It already is in development(see [here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/pull/602)(clearnet) or [here](/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/issues/view/?1P4w4Rvh4vS9r6G5xTiSh8qEW87EKZtnJB/3@1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC)), so we just need to wait.

@xeu100: Ok, feel free to ask me, if you have questions and I see if I can help you. I might take some time to answer though.

Probably never. Well, that makes it sound way meaner, than it actually is. The reason for 'probably never' is, that ZeroTalk, ZeroMe and ZeroID were never supposed to be finished zites. They were intended to be demos of what devs could build in ZeroNet and to show them how the api can be utilized.

However a thing to keep in mind is, that Tor on the raspberry pi architecture(raspbian != debian) has been broken/flawed in the past. I'm not sure how the situation on that is right now, but it would be wise not to bank on the security of Tor on an pi, unless you know that this has been resolved.

If you want to donate more time to zeronet you could skim through some of the issues on the [ZeroNet repo](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues)(Clearnet) and solve some of them you feel comfortable tackling with your skill level.

You could forward port 80 to 43110, using iptables([here](https://www.systutorials.com/816/port-forwarding-using-iptables/)(Clearnet) is a tutorial for that) (or a less brain melting package).
Also don't forget to have a firewall installed  and active and to not have the ssh port at the default 22.

That's because you don't have much space left. Every hub has a 'max_size' each user can post(images don't count towards that, they are considered 'optional' and are grouped into the 'max_size_optional' limit). This is defined in the users/content.json for your hub(MoonHub):
```json
  "permission_rules": {
   ".*": {
    "files_allowed": "(data.json|avatar.jpg|avatar.png)",
    "max_size": 50000,
    "max_size_optional": 100000000
   },
   "bitid/.*@zeroid.bit": {"max_size": 60000},
   "bitmsg/.*@zeroid.bit": {"max_size": 60000}
  }
```
Each of them are in bytes, so you have 50kB of text and 100MB of images by default.

If you want more you'll have to ask the hub runner if they can give you a raise, which they usually will do.
In your case that would be @Nofish: .

I'm currently also waiting on a raise over on orange hub, so in case nofish reads this: Please raise mine, too.
  
Also: Happy New Year, to you as well!

@Tusiko: Looking at the specs of the development boards, I think they will turn out to be (fairly) high end phones. So you'll probably not be seeing issues in daily usage.
Also: Has anyone found the official specs for the Librem 5? The only thing I found were the dev-board specs [here](https://developer.puri.sm/Librem5/Hardware_Reference.html)(Clearnet).
Hi!

@Klu9: I completely forgot about ZeroWiki. I'll see when I have time to write something up, but I think I'll add some things there.
Alternatively I could just recycle the explanations on PedoHub, do you think these are clear enough?
Text of that section:
~
How does ZeroMe work?
ZeroMe is a merger zite. That means, that content storage and content display are separated.
The zite ZeroMe itself manages, how the content is displayed, while the hubs store the actual content you browse on ZeroMe.
There are two types of hubs. User registry hubs
and User content hubs.
~
User registry hubs:
These hubs are used for the New users and Suggested users sections on ZeroMe.
Only one of these does currently exists. It is the ZeroMe user registry and is hard coded into all (current) ZeroMe implementations.
The content.json of that hub only allows the providers ZeroID and ZeroVerse.
That has the effect, that if you register with neither of them, your account will not show up in those sections.
Depending on your situation, this could be desirable or undesirable, since all registered users will show up in both sections will show everyone that uses ZeroMe.
~
User content hubs:
These are where your profile, posts, comments and replies are stored.
There are many hubs out there(this hub being one of them). A list of most of them can be found on Get All Hub.
Every post you make will be stored on the hub, that you registered on. If you comment on a post, that is not stored on your hub, than your content is stored twice, once on the hub you're on and once on the hub of the user you wrote a comment to. Since all content is stored on hubs, you can only see posts from hubs you already visited(downloaded) once before.
In other words: The more hubs you have, the more posts you're able to see (the posts in the Everyone section of ZeroMe).
Even though ZeroMe does not have an moderation system, hub owners(this can be either hub runners or anyone that has the private key of the hub) have absolute power over that hub. If they so chose to, they are able to delete posts, users and the hub itself(by turning the entire hub into an blank page, for example), however they cannot meaningfully edit user data and deleting posts/users requires work, that is likely to be noticed, by more tech savvy people and everyone, that happened to be also using that hub at that time.

Nice. However,
>With the option tor always all tracker are forced to use the Tor network, so nobody can see your real IP.

This is not what it does. `--tor always` only uses tor to communicate with other peers. This is done using an .onion address instead of an ip address peers that offer their ip are(to the best of my knowledge) ignored by any client, that runs in tor only mode. Connections to all tracker are **still** made over a normal internet connection. The option to disable that as well is `--trackers_proxy tor`. A proper tor only setup can be archived by using this config file:
```
[global]
tor = always
trackers_proxy = tor
force_encryption
disable_udp
```
Tor is can only communicate over tcp, so udp is worthless in tor always mode. For convenience, you can also add `open_browser = False` in the config or use `--open_browser False` option.
There is some more detail in my '[How to install Zeronet on QubesOS](/1PexoLogqCsGAwYEUNqKnmzccg1r5tzCZ3/?Post:5:How+to+install+Zeronet+on+QubesOS)' post on my Blog.

Yes there is.

There is the option to mute users and zites, that you don't like(or legally can view where you live). Build on top of that are blocklists, zites that contain users and zites someone else put on there. If enabled, your ZeroNet client will automatically treat every user and zite on that list as if you've muted them.
This all is local(on your computer), for global(on everyones computer) bans, there isn't really anything there. The owner of a zite can choose to implement moderating features or moderate himself(because zite owners=gods). However most zites do not remove content even if they have a moderation system, but rather hide it by default(in case of millchan) and a zite owner actually moderating the public content is rare, which has many reasons, but the most common one is that when moderation stops and censorship starts is something subjective, so most owners just don't moderate at all.

On here, for example, the only time(to my knowlage) something was actually removed(banned), was when someone posted childporn. Nofish stepped in and deleted it on the hubs he owned(most of the color ones), however the ones that where not on his hubs are actually still there, because the owner of that hub has left zeronet some time ago.

Well technically it isn't limited to one hub, ZeroMe will happily register you to many hubs at once. However, this generally results in weird bugs and loss of data, because ZeroMe just wasn't designed to be that way and gets really confused by profiles that are on multiple hubs.  
  
In theory, you could use [ZeroMe unfuck](/1QHbf72f4vdx3QAxN1LTN9KP19J428Q85R) to switch hubs, but this can also result in some weird bugs later on.  
  
Also, why would you want to follow an entire hub?
Pretty good so far, I'd say.

Please don't take that the wrong way, but you hit about every bad security practice I can think of:
- (presumably) Homebrew crypto
- Precompiled executable only
- No source code given
- No authentication(signature)
- Use of dyndns(a 'free' one)
- https broken(forced to use http)

Due to the strong fingerprint protection by the Tor Browser ZeroMe cannot use the 'browser way' of generating images. This is why all your uploads appear white. You can go to `about:config` and set `privacy.resistFingerprinting` to false and you should be able to upload again. Don't forget to turn it back on, though as it severely limits the amount of protection the Tor Browser can give you on any other website. Another way would be to **politely** ask nofish(the dev of ZeroMe) to make ZeroMe work on Tor Browser.  
  
@Realjohndoe: The issue isn't Tor it's the Tor Browser and MeroMe.

@Hozero: Well, thanks to the mainstream(and quite some not so mainstream) media darknets and p2p networks have the reputation of being only for child porn and most people believe that. This includes those who post child porn as well(not necessarily pedos, by the way). A reminder does not hurt, but child porn will get everyone who downloaded it and didn't protect themselves into serious trouble, in many countries regardless of context or intend. I don't like this situation either, but the risk is simply too high.

That's why there are dedicated places for child porn, you can't keep people from posting it in a censorship free platform. But when the consequences are this high, it's a really good idea to (at least try to) have a central place for it, so you can easily avoid it.
